bestBHT.bht: Jesus firmly rebukes a man who seeks his involvement in a family dispute, asserting that he is not appointed as a judge or arbiter in worldly matters. He emphasizes that his kingdom is not of this world, urging his followers to render unto Caesar what is Caesar's. Jesus' primary focus is on spiritual concerns, preaching the Gospel and attending to the welfare of souls. By declining to intermeddle with secular affairs, he upholds the significant influence of religious teachers in external life while maintaining his position as a spiritual leader.

Henry Alford: Man... a word of solemn reproof.
The man also forms a definite subject for you to refer to...
This question is expressed in almost the very words of the Egyptian rejecting the arbitration of Moses.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Contrast this style of address with 'my friends'...
The influence of religious teachers in the external relations of life has ever been immense...
Whenever they intermeddle DIRECTLY with secular and political matters, the spell of that influence is broken.
Albert Barnes: It is not my business to settle controversies of this kind.
Jesus came for another purpose - to preach the gospel, and so to bring people to 'a willingness to do' right.
The appropriate business of ministers of the gospel is to attend to spiritual concerns.
Philip Schaff: Man. In a tone of reproof, as in Romans 2:1; Romans 9:20.
Who made me a judge? etc. Moses assumed this position and was reproached for it by one of his countrymen in language closely resembling this (Exodus 2:14); Christ expressly rejects it.

A purely worldly case, our Lord declines to consider. It has been remarked that He repeatedly considered the question of divorce; which shows that marriage and divorce are not purely secular matters, but of a religious character.
Archibald T. Robertson: Jesus repudiates the position of judge or arbiter in this family fuss.
Jesus is rendering unto Caesar the things of Caesar and shows that his kingdom is not of this world.
The word for divider or arbiter is a late word and occurs here only in the N.T.
John Gill: The reason why Christ avoided meddling with it, was not because it is unlawful for Christians to concern themselves in arbitrations about civil affairs, and in making up family differences, which is very commendable; but lest by such a step, he should give occasion to them, to conclude he was a temporal king.
His business lay not in civil affairs, and the management of them; but in spiritual concerns, in preaching the Gospel, and doing good to the souls of men; wherefore this was out of his province.

This man seems to have disturbed Christ in his public work, and was of such a worldly spirit, as to prefer the care of his secular affairs, to the hearing of the word, and the welfare of his immortal soul.
John Wesley: Who made me a judge? — In worldly things. His kingdom is not of this world.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 12:14, Jesus responds to a man with solemn reproof, rejecting the position of judge or arbiter in a family dispute. He emphasizes that his kingdom is not of this world, rendering unto Caesar the things of Caesar. The question of who made him a judge in worldly matters is reminiscent of Moses being reproached for assuming that role. Jesus' focus is on spiritual concerns, preaching the Gospel and attending to the welfare of souls, rather than meddling in secular affairs. His avoidance of involvement in the man's secular affairs is not to be interpreted as a rejection of Christians engaging in arbitrations about civil matters, but rather to prevent any misconceptions about his role as a temporal king.

In response to a man's question, Jesus reproves his attempt to involve him in a family dispute. He rejects the role of judge or arbiter in these worldly matters, emphasizing that his kingdom is not of this world. By refusing to intermingle in secular affairs, Jesus showcases the distinction between his mission of preaching the Gospel and attending to spiritual concerns, rather than getting entangled in external conflicts. His focus on the welfare of souls over secular matters is clear as he declines to engage in a dispute that pertains to mundane affairs unrelated to his kingdom.

In response to a man's request, Jesus sternly reproves his attempt to involve him in a family dispute. He rejects the role of judge or arbiter in these worldly matters, pointing out that his kingdom is not of this world. Jesus is focused on spiritual concerns, emphasizing the distinction between his mission of preaching the Gospel and attending to secular affairs. By declining involvement in a dispute unrelated to his spiritual authority, he upholds the significance of his role as a teacher of divine truths.

Jesus firmly rebukes a man who seeks his involvement in a family dispute, asserting that he is not appointed as a judge or arbiter in worldly matters. He emphasizes that his kingdom is not of this world, urging his followers to render unto Caesar what is Caesar's. Jesus' primary focus is on spiritual concerns, preaching the Gospel and attending to the welfare of souls. By declining to intermeddle with secular affairs, he upholds the significant influence of religious teachers in external life while maintaining his position as a spiritual leader.

Jesus responds to a man's request by rebuking him, refusing to act as a judge or arbiter in a family dispute. He states that his kingdom is not of this world and cautions against religious teachers becoming entangled in secular and political matters. Jesus prioritizes spiritual concerns and the preaching of the Gospel, distancing himself from worldly affairs. His refusal to intervene in a purely secular case reinforces the religious nature of marriage and divorce, highlighting the importance of his role in addressing matters of the soul.
